yadlp

This challenge follows a similar structure to a commonly seen style of crypto CTF challenges that involve solving the discrete logarithm problem in some group other than the usual (Z/pZ)×(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^\times(Z/pZ)×. The general approach is to figure out some information about what the group elements are like, and then try to find an isomorphism from the group to a group where we can easily solve the discrete logarithm problem.

Group Structure Part I

We'll see that the group we are dealing with in the challenge is the set of points on some hyperbola over Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​. Although the operations defined in the handout code are called "addition" and "multiplication", it'll be helpful to use multiplication and exponentiation notation. When we say "elements", we usually mean points on the hyperbola, which are represented as tuples (x,y)∈Fp×Fp(x, y) \in \mathbb{F}_p \times \mathbb{F}_p(x,y)∈Fp​×Fp​ with addition operation defined as:

(x1,y1)⋅(x2,y2)=(x1x2+Dy1y2,x1y2+x2y1+2y1y2)(x_1, y_1) \cdot (x_2, y_2) = (x_1 x_2 + D y_1 y_2, x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_1 + 2 y_1 y_2)(x1​,y1​)⋅(x2​,y2​)=(x1​x2​+Dy1​y2​,x1​y2​+x2​y1​+2y1​y2​)

The rand_element function gives us even more information about elements in this group. In fact, we can use it to get an explicit relation that all elements satisfy. The function first generates a random x∈Fpx \in \mathbb{F}_px∈Fp​, then computes yyy as

y=x+x2(D+1)−DDy = \frac{x + \sqrt{x^2 (D+1) - D}}{D}y=Dx+x2(D+1)−D​​

Rearranging, we get

(Dy−x)2=x2(D+1)−D  ⟹  D2y2−2Dxy+x2=Dx2+x2−D  ⟹  Dx2+2Dxy−D2y2=D  ⟹  x2+2xy−Dy2≡1(modp)since D≠0\begin{aligned} (Dy - x)^2 &= x^2(D+1) - D \\ \implies D^2 y^2 - 2Dxy + x^2 &= Dx^2 + x^2 - D \\ \implies Dx^2 + 2Dxy - D^2 y^2 &= D \\ \implies x^2 + 2xy - Dy^2 &\equiv 1 \pmod p \qquad \text{since $D \neq 0$} \end{aligned}(Dy−x)2⟹D2y2−2Dxy+x2⟹Dx2+2Dxy−D2y2⟹x2+2xy−Dy2​=x2(D+1)−D=Dx2+x2−D=D≡1(modp)since D=0​

It can be checked that the set of solutions to this equation, equipped with addition operation above indeed does form a group. We'll call this group H\mathcal{H}H.

Diophantine equations of the form x2−Dy2=1x^2 - Dy^2 = 1x2−Dy2=1 are known as Pell equations and are well documented in the literature. We'll see later that the equation we found from the rand_element can be written as a Pell equation, and use that for analysing the group even more.

Challenge Analysis

For now we'll take a look at how the flag is hidden and what we'll need to recover it. The 48 byte flag is broken up into 6 blocks of 8 bytes each. These blocks are represented as the integers m1,…,m6m_1, \ldots, m_6m1​,…,m6​. Then, for some randomly generated elements g1,…,g6g_1, \ldots, g_6g1​,…,g6​, the value c=g1m1⋯g6m6c = g_1^{m_1} \cdots g_6^{m_6}c=g1m1​​⋯g6m6​​ is computed.

Given ccc and the gig_igi​, the goal is to recover the mim_imi​. This is known as the t-multiple discrete logarithm problem, and in this case, we can solve it by solving the discrete logarithm problem in H\mathcal{H}H, combined with lattice techniques.

Let qqq be the order of H\mathcal{H}H and let ggg be a generator of H\mathcal{H}H (we will see later that H\mathcal{H}H is cyclic). Define the discrete logarithm to the base ggg as log⁡g:H→Zq\log_g : \mathcal{H} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_qlogg​:H→Zq​, that, for any h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H, gives us a value x=log⁡g(h)x = \log_g(h)x=logg​(h) such that gx=hg^x = hgx=h. It can be shown that this map is a homomorphism, so log⁡g(h1h2)=log⁡g(h1)+log⁡g(h2)\log_g(h_1 h_2) = \log_g(h_1) + \log_g(h_2)logg​(h1​h2​)=logg​(h1​)+logg​(h2​). Therefore,

log⁡g(c)=log⁡g(g1m1⋯g6m6)log⁡g(c)=log⁡g(g1m1)+⋯+log⁡g(g6m6)log⁡g(c)=m1log⁡g(g1)+⋯+m6log⁡g(g6)\begin{aligned} \log_g(c) &= \log_g(g_1^{m_1} \cdots g_6^{m_6}) \\ \log_g(c) &= \log_g(g_1^{m_1}) + \cdots + \log_g(g_6^{m_6}) \\ \log_g(c) &= m_1\log_g(g_1) + \cdots + m_6 \log_g(g_6) \\ \end{aligned}logg​(c)logg​(c)logg​(c)​=logg​(g1m1​​⋯g6m6​​)=logg​(g1m1​​)+⋯+logg​(g6m6​​)=m1​logg​(g1​)+⋯+m6​logg​(g6​)​

Since we're working in Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​, we can equivalently write

log⁡g(c)≡m1log⁡g(g1)+⋯+m6log⁡g(g6)(modq)\log_g(c) \equiv m_1\log_g(g_1) + \cdots + m_6\log_g(g_6) \pmod qlogg​(c)≡m1​logg​(g1​)+⋯+m6​logg​(g6​)(modq)

But since the mim_imi​ are relatively small (~62 bits) compared to qqq (which we will determine later), we can solve for the mim_imi​ using lattice techniques. Specifically, consider the lattice generated by the rows of the matrix

[log⁡g(g1)1log⁡g(g2)1⋮⋱log⁡g(g6)1log⁡g(c)1q]\begin{bmatrix} \log_g(g_1) & 1 \\ \log_g(g_2) & & 1 \\ \vdots & & & \ddots \\ \log_g(g_6) & & & & 1 \\ \log_g(c) & & & & & 1 \\ q \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​logg​(g1​)logg​(g2​)⋮logg​(g6​)logg​(c)q​1​1​⋱​1​1​⎦⎤​

Notice that m1m_1m1​ times the first row, plus m2m_2m2​ times the second row, etc. take 111 times the seventh row, and an appropriate multiple of the last row, gives the short vector

(0,262,262,262,262,262,262,−1)(0, 2^{62}, 2^{62}, 2^{62}, 2^{62}, 2^{62}, 2^{62}, -1)(0,262,262,262,262,262,262,−1)

which can be found with lattice basis reduction algorithms such as LLL.

Group Structure Part II

Group Order

All we need left to solve the challenge is a way to solve the discrete logarithm problem in H\mathcal{H}H. Determining the group order is a good first step as we could use it to try and see if there is an isomorphism between H\mathcal{H}H and an additive group of integers of the same order where the discrete logarithm is trivially solved by division. However, it turns out that the order of H\mathcal{H}H is p+1p+1p+1 and that H\mathcal{H}H is isomorphic to the cyclic subgroup of Fp2\mathbb{F}_{p^2}Fp2​ of order p+1p+1p+1. We follow a similar approach to [1] for the proof.

Claim. Let H⊂Fp×Fp\mathcal{H} \subset \mathbb{F}_p \times \mathbb{F}_pH⊂Fp​×Fp​ be the set of solutions to the equation

x2+2xy−Dy2≡1(modp)x^2 + 2xy - Dy^2 \equiv 1 \pmod px2+2xy−Dy2≡1(modp)

Assume that (D+1p)=−1\left(\dfrac{D+1}{p}\right) = -1(pD+1​)=−1 (this is true for the challenge parameters). Then, H≅S\mathcal{H} \cong SH≅S where S≤Fp2S \leq \mathbb{F}_{p^2}S≤Fp2​ is the cyclic subgroup of Fp2\mathbb{F}_{p^2}Fp2​ of order p+1p+1p+1.

Proof. First, note that (x+y)2−(D+1)y2=x2+2xy−Dy2(x+y)^2 - (D+1)y^2 = x^2 + 2xy - Dy^2(x+y)2−(D+1)y2=x2+2xy−Dy2, so it suffices to show that the set of solutions to the equation (x+y)2−(D+1)y2≡1(modp)(x+y)^2 - (D+1)y^2 \equiv 1 \pmod p(x+y)2−(D+1)y2≡1(modp) (equipped with the addition operation as defined above) is isomorphic to SSS. Let f(W)=W2−(D+1)f(W) = W^2 - (D+1)f(W)=W2−(D+1). Note that f(W)f(W)f(W) is irreducible as it is of degree 2 and has no roots, since D+1D+1D+1 has no square in Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ by assumption. Therefore Fp2≅Fp[W]/⟨f(W)⟩\mathbb{F}_{p^2} \cong \mathbb{F}_p[W]/\langle f(W) \rangleFp2​≅Fp​[W]/⟨f(W)⟩. Now, if α∈S\alpha \in Sα∈S, then αp+1=1\alpha^{p+1} = 1αp+1=1 (since SSS has order p+1p+1p+1). But we can write α=r+sW\alpha = r + sWα=r+sW for r,s∈Fpr,s \in \mathbb{F}_pr,s∈Fp​. So,

αp+1=(r+sW)p(r+sW)=(rp+spWp)(r+sW)(x+y)p=xp+yp for all x,y∈Fp=(r+sWp)(r+sW)xp−1=1 for all x∈Fp=(r−sW)(r+sW)Wp=W(W2)p−12=W(D+1)p−12=−W=r2−s2W2=r2−(D+1)s2W2=D+1\begin{aligned} \alpha^{p+1} &= (r + sW)^p (r + sW) \\ &= (r^p + s^pW^p)(r + sW) &&\quad (x+y)^p = x^p + y^p \text{ for all } x, y \in \mathbb{F}_p \\ &= (r + sW^p)(r + sW) &&\quad x^{p-1} = 1 \text{ for all } x \in \mathbb{F}_p \\ &= (r - sW)(r + sW) &&\quad W^p = W(W^2)^{\frac{p-1}{2}} = W(D+1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}} = -W \\ &= r^2 - s^2 W^2 \\ &= r^2 - (D+1)s^2 &&\quad W^2 = D+1 \end{aligned}αp+1​=(r+sW)p(r+sW)=(rp+spWp)(r+sW)=(r+sWp)(r+sW)=(r−sW)(r+sW)=r2−s2W2=r2−(D+1)s2​​(x+y)p=xp+yp for all x,y∈Fp​xp−1=1 for all x∈Fp​Wp=W(W2)2p−1​=W(D+1)2p−1​=−WW2=D+1​

So, if we take r=x+yr = x+yr=x+y and s=ys = ys=y, then we see that αp+1=1=(x+y)2−(D+1)y2\alpha^{p+1} = 1 = (x+y)^2 - (D+1)y^2αp+1=1=(x+y)2−(D+1)y2. Therefore, we have the bijection φ:H→S,(x,y)↦(x+y)+yW\varphi : \mathcal{H} \rightarrow S, (x, y) \mapsto (x+y) + yWφ:H→S,(x,y)↦(x+y)+yW. To see that this is a homomorphism, let (x1,y1),(x2,y2)∈H(x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2) \in \mathcal{H}(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​)∈H. Then

φ((x1,y1)⋅(x2,y2))=φ((x1x2+Dy1y2,x1y2+x2y1+2y1y2))=(x1x2+x1y2+x2y1+(D+2)y1y2)+(x1y2+x2y1+2y1y2)W\begin{aligned} \varphi((x_1, y_1) \cdot (x_2, y_2)) &= \varphi((x_1 x_2 + D y_1 y_2, x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_1 + 2 y_1 y_2)) \\ &= (x_1 x_2 + x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_1 + (D+2) y_1 y_2) + (x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_1 + 2 y_1 y_2) W \end{aligned}φ((x1​,y1​)⋅(x2​,y2​))​=φ((x1​x2​+Dy1​y2​,x1​y2​+x2​y1​+2y1​y2​))=(x1​x2​+x1​y2​+x2​y1​+(D+2)y1​y2​)+(x1​y2​+x2​y1​+2y1​y2​)W​

But

φ((x1,y1))φ((x2,y2))=((x1+y1)+y1W)((x2+y2)+y2W)=(x1+y1)(x2+y2)+(x1+y1)y2W+(x2+y2)y1W+y1y2W2=(x1x2+x1y2+x2y1+y1y2)+(x1y2+x2y1+2y1y2)W+(D+1)y1y2=(x1x2+x1y2+x2y1+(D+2)y1y2)+(x1y2+x2y1+2y1y2)W\begin{aligned} \varphi((x_1, y_1)) \varphi((x_2, y_2)) &= ((x_1 + y_1) + y_1 W)((x_2 + y_2) + y_2 W) \\ &= (x_1 + y_1)(x_2 + y_2) + (x_1 + y_1) y_2 W + (x_2 + y_2) y_1 W + y_1 y_2 W^2 \\ &= (x_1 x_2 + x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_1 + y_1 y_2) + (x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_1 + 2 y_1 y_2) W + (D+1) y_1 y_2 \\ &= (x_1 x_2 + x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_1 + (D+2) y_1 y_2) + (x_1 y_2 + x_2 y_1 + 2 y_1 y_2) W \end{aligned}φ((x1​,y1​))φ((x2​,y2​))​=((x1​+y1​)+y1​W)((x2​+y2​)+y2​W)=(x1​+y1​)(x2​+y2​)+(x1​+y1​)y2​W+(x2​+y2​)y1​W+y1​y2​W2=(x1​x2​+x1​y2​+x2​y1​+y1​y2​)+(x1​y2​+x2​y1​+2y1​y2​)W+(D+1)y1​y2​=(x1​x2​+x1​y2​+x2​y1​+(D+2)y1​y2​)+(x1​y2​+x2​y1​+2y1​y2​)W​

So we have φ((x1,y1)⋅(x2,y2))=φ((x1,y1))φ((x2,y2))\varphi((x_1, y_1) \cdot (x_2, y_2)) = \varphi((x_1, y_1)) \varphi((x_2, y_2))φ((x1​,y1​)⋅(x2​,y2​))=φ((x1​,y1​))φ((x2​,y2​)).

Therefore φ\varphiφ is an isomorphism, and H≅S\mathcal{H} \cong SH≅S.

If we take a look at the actual values in the challenge, we'll see that p+1p+1p+1 is smooth, with the largest factor being 32 bits! This is a hint that we're on the right path, since we'll be able to solve the discrete logarithm problem in a reasonable time with Pohlig-Hellman.

Inverse Elements

By this point, we've pretty much already solved the challenge, but as a bonus, we can find the inverse elements of H\mathcal{H}H. Although the solution script doesn't do this, this has the advantage of speed over using the isomorphism found above since the operations are slightly faster (than operations in Fp2\mathbb{F}_{p^2}Fp2​). Recall the addition formula

(x,y)⋅(x′,y′)=(xx′+Dyy′,xy′+x′y+2yy′)(x, y) \cdot (x', y') = (xx' + Dyy', xy' + x'y + 2yy')(x,y)⋅(x′,y′)=(xx′+Dyy′,xy′+x′y+2yy′)

The identity element is clearly (1,0)(1, 0)(1,0), so to find the inverse element of (x,y)(x, y)(x,y), we want to find (x′,y′)(x', y')(x′,y′) such that (x,y)⋅(x′,y′)=(1,0)(x, y) \cdot (x', y') = (1, 0)(x,y)⋅(x′,y′)=(1,0). Let (x′,y′)=(x+2y,−y)(x', y') = (x + 2y, -y)(x′,y′)=(x+2y,−y). Then

(x,y)⋅(x′,y′)=(x,y)⋅(x+2y,−y)=(x(x+2y)−Dy2,−xy+(x+2y)y−2y2)=(x2+2xy−Dy2,−xy+xy+2y2−2y2)=(1,0)\begin{aligned} (x, y) \cdot (x', y') &= (x, y) \cdot (x + 2y, -y) \\ &= (x(x + 2y) - Dy^2, -xy + (x + 2y)y - 2y^2) \\ &= (x^2 + 2xy - Dy^2, -xy + xy + 2y^2 - 2y^2) \\ &= (1, 0) \end{aligned}(x,y)⋅(x′,y′)​=(x,y)⋅(x+2y,−y)=(x(x+2y)−Dy2,−xy+(x+2y)y−2y2)=(x2+2xy−Dy2,−xy+xy+2y2−2y2)=(1,0)​

So (x,y)−1=(x+2y,−y)(x, y)^{-1} = (x + 2y, -y)(x,y)−1=(x+2y,−y).

Another advantage of figuring out inverse elements is that you can solve the challenge without finding the isomorphism to Fp2\mathbb{F}_{p^2}Fp2​ by guessing that the order is p+1p+1p+1 since it is smooth, and then implementing Pohlig-Hellman and BSGS to use the addition, multiplication and inverse operations.

References

  • [1] Elliptic Curve Public Key Cryptosystems - Menezes 93

power sign

Challenge Overview

We are given the code running on a server that implements a signature scheme. We can ask the server to sign one message, then we are challenged to forge a signature for a random message.

The signature scheme resembles the Rabin signature algorithm. The public key is an RSA modulus N=pqN = pqN=pq whose prime factorisation is the private key. A message MMM is signed by first computing a randomised hash H(M,u)H(M, u)H(M,u) (where uuu is random) of MMM. If H(M,u)H(M, u)H(M,u) has a square root modulo NNN, a square root xxx modulo NNN is computed and the signature (x,u)(x, u)(x,u) is outputted. Otherwise, we try again with a different uuu. Note that computing square roots modulo NNN, or even determining whether a number has a square root modulo NNN is equivalent to factoring NNN. To verify a signature (x,u)(x, u)(x,u) for the message MMM, we simply check that the equality x2≡H(m,u)(modN)x^2 \equiv H(m, u) \pmod Nx2≡H(m,u)(modN) holds.

In the challenge, the primes generated are of the form p≡3(mod4)p \equiv 3 \pmod 4p≡3(mod4). This is done because if ppp is a prime such that p≡3(mod4)p \equiv 3 \pmod 4p≡3(mod4), then if a square root of a∈{0,…,p−1}a \in \{ 0, \ldots, p-1 \}a∈{0,…,p−1} exists, it can be easily computed as ±ap+14mod  p\pm a^{\frac{p+1}{4}} \mod p±a4p+1​modp. To compute a square root of ccc modulo NNN, we compute square roots of ccc modulo ppp and modulo qqq, then combine them with the Chinese Remainder Theorem.

Security of Rabin Signatures

Before we proceed, we'll take a look at an easy attack against a simplified variant of the Rabin signature algorithm. Specifically, we consider a variant that does not use a hash function at all, i.e. to sign a message MMM the signer simply computes a square root of MMM modulo NNN. For simplicity, we assume that all the messages to be signed actually do have square roots modulo NNN, though it does not really matter. There is one trivial attack; anyone can "forge" a valid signature for MMM if MMM is a perfect square. For example, if M=9M = 9M=9, then x=3x = 3x=3 is a valid signature since x2≡m(modN)x^2 \equiv m \pmod Nx2≡m(modN).

More interestingly however, it turns out that we can recover the private key given access to a signing oracle. We do this by choosing a random x<Nx < Nx<N and ask the oracle to sign x2mod  Nx^2 \mod Nx2modN. It returns a square root yyy of x2x^2x2 modulo NNN. Now, if y≠±x(modN)y \neq \pm x \pmod Ny=±x(modN), then we have

x2≡y2(modN)  ⟹  x2−y2≡0(modN)  ⟹  x2−y2=kNfor some k  ⟹  (x−y)(x+y)=kN\begin{aligned} x^2 &\equiv y^2 \pmod N \\ \implies x^2 - y^2 &\equiv 0 \pmod N \\ \implies x^2 - y^2 &= kN \quad \text{for some $k$} \\ \implies (x-y)(x+y) &= kN \end{aligned}x2⟹x2−y2⟹x2−y2⟹(x−y)(x+y)​≡y2(modN)≡0(modN)=kNfor some k=kN​

so gcd⁡(x−y,N)\gcd(x-y, N)gcd(x−y,N) reveals a nontrivial factor of NNN.

The Hash Function

This section and the next are somewhat algebra-heavy and basic results from algebra are used without proof for brevity. It may be worthwhile to read up on finite fields, field extensions and Galois theory (for later) if they are unfamiliar concepts.

We learned the importance of a good, randomised hash function in the previous section. And more importantly, we learned that a hash function which is simply the identity map (i.e. sends any input to itself), is completely insecure. We will now take a look at the hash function in the challenge.

Choose a composite integer nnn and a proper divisor mmm (in the challenge we have n=15,m=3n = 15, m = 3n=15,m=3). Let rrr be the smallest prime number following NNN, where NNN is the signer's public key. We will work in an extension field K=Frn≅Fr[x]/(f)K = \mathbb{F}_{r^n} \cong \mathbb{F}_r[x]/(f)K=Frn​≅Fr​[x]/(f) of Fr\mathbb{F}_rFr​, where f∈Fr[x]f \in \mathbb{F}_r[x]f∈Fr​[x] is a public degree nnn irreducible polynomial. Let z=x+(f)z = x + (f)z=x+(f). Then zzz generates KKK and {1,z,z2,…,zn−1}\{ 1, z, z^2, \ldots, z^{n-1} \}{1,z,z2,…,zn−1} is basis for KKK when viewed as an nnn-dimensional Fr\mathbb{F}_rFr​-vector space. That is, elements in KKK can be written in the form a0+a1z+⋯+an−1zn−1a_0 + a_1 z + \cdots + a_{n-1} z^{n-1}a0​+a1​z+⋯+an−1​zn−1 where ai∈Fra_i \in \mathbb{F}_rai​∈Fr​.

The randomised hash function HHH takes as input a message MMM and an integer uuu. Write MMM in terms of powers of rrr:

M=M0+M1r+M2r2+⋯+MkrkM = M_0 + M_1 r + M_2 r^2 + \cdots + M_k r^kM=M0​+M1​r+M2​r2+⋯+Mk​rk

where Mi<rM_i < rMi​<r. Then, MMM is converted to an element hhh in KKK by computing

h=Mk+Mk−1z+Mk−2z2+⋯+M0zkh = M_k + M_{k-1} z + M_{k-2} z^2 + \cdots + M_0 z^kh=Mk​+Mk−1​z+Mk−2​z2+⋯+M0​zk

To obtain the hash, the function computes (h+uz)rm(h + uz)^{r^m}(h+uz)rm which we write as

(h+uz)rm=a0+a1z+⋯+an−1zn−1(h + uz)^{r^m} = a_0 + a_1 z + \cdots + a_{n-1} z^{n-1}(h+uz)rm=a0​+a1​z+⋯+an−1​zn−1

The output is a0a_0a0​.

Choosing a Message to be Signed

After the server provides us with its public key, it prompts us to send a message to be signed. Note that (in the sign function) uuu isn't chosen randomly; it starts at 111 and increments until H(M,u)H(M, u)H(M,u) is a square. There is also a peculiar restriction on the message; it has to be larger than NmN^mNm and smaller than NnN^nNn.

If we were able to send messages of any size for the server to sign, we can easily find a message that will help us to recover the private key. Specifically, we would choose a random s<Ns < Ns<N and send the message (r−1)+(s2mod  N)r(r - 1) + (s^2 \mod N) r(r−1)+(s2modN)r. The hash function will convert this to h=(s2mod  N)+(r−1)zh = (s^2 \mod N) + (r - 1)zh=(s2modN)+(r−1)z and output the constant term in (h+uz)rm(h + uz)^{r^m}(h+uz)rm which happens to just be s2mod  Ns^2 \mod Ns2modN since all elements a∈Fra \in \mathbb{F}_ra∈Fr​ satisfy ar=aa^r = aar=a by Fermat's Little Theorem. So when the server signs this, we have the exact same situation as the attack described two sections ago. However, the size check prevents this attack.

Recall that the identity map is insecure as a hash function for the reasons given two sections ago. It turns out that our particular hash function is the identity map on a specific subset, or rather, subfield of KKK other than Fr\mathbb{F}_rFr​. We have

H(M,u)=(h+uz)rmH(M, u) = (h + uz)^{r^m}H(M,u)=(h+uz)rm

where hhh is the element in KKK we obtain by converting MMM. We can write this as a composition H=f∘gH = f \circ gH=f∘g where

g(M,u)=h+uzf(x)=xrmg(M, u) = h + uz \qquad f(x) = x^{r^m}g(M,u)=h+uzf(x)=xrm

The goal will be to find fixed points of HHH, which can be done by finding fixed points of fff since we can easily manipulate the result of g(M,u)g(M, u)g(M,u) by carefully choosing MMM. Fixed points of fff satisfy

f(x)=x  ⟹  xrm=x  ⟹  xrm−x=0f(x) = x \implies x^{r^m} = x \implies x^{r^m} - x = 0f(x)=x⟹xrm=x⟹xrm−x=0

Note that for a finite field EEE of order rmr^mrm, the elements of EEE are given by the roots of xrm−xx^{r^m} - xxrm−x. This follows from the fact that the multiplicative group E×=E−{0}E^\times = E - \{ 0 \}E×=E−{0} is a cyclic group of order rm−1r^m - 1rm−1, so if α∈E\alpha \in Eα∈E, then αrm−1=1\alpha^{r^m - 1} = 1αrm−1=1 and so αrm=α\alpha^{r^m} = \alphaαrm=α. That E×E^\timesE× is cyclic of order rm−1r^m - 1rm−1 follows from the structure theorem for finite abelian groups which states that any finite abelian group is a direct product of cyclic groups. There are a lot of references online for these results and their proofs.

So, to solve for the roots of xrm−xx^{r^m} - xxrm−x we simply need to look at elements in the finite field EEE of order rmr^mrm. Since mmm divides nnn, then this field is actually a subfield of KKK because if xxx satisfies xrm=xx^{r^m} = xxrm=x, then it also satisfies

xrn=xrkm=x(rm)k=x(rm)(rm)k−1=(xrm)(rm)k−1=x(rm)k−1⋮=x\begin{aligned} x^{r^n} &= x^{r^{km}} \\ &= x^{(r^m)^k} \\ &= x^{(r^m)(r^m)^{k-1}} \\ &= (x^{r^m})^{(r^m)^{k-1}} \\ &= x^{(r^m)^{k-1}} \\ &\quad \vdots \\ &= x \end{aligned}xrn​=xrkm=x(rm)k=x(rm)(rm)k−1=(xrm)(rm)k−1=x(rm)k−1⋮=x​

(and it can also be checked that EEE actually is a field). This is good for us as it means we can write the elements in terms of zzz which is what the server will be expecting.

Let zEz_EzE​ be a generator of EEE. Because EEE is a subfield of KKK, then zEz_EzE​ can be written as

zE=e0+e1z+⋯en−1zn−1z_E = e_0 + e_1 z + \cdots e_{n-1} z^{n-1}zE​=e0​+e1​z+⋯en−1​zn−1

where ei∈Fre_i \in \mathbb{F}_rei​∈Fr​. Choose a random s<Ns < Ns<N. We will want to find an element in KKK of the form

(s2mod  N)+a1z+⋯anzn−1(s^2 \mod N) + a_1 z + \cdots a_n z^{n-1}(s2modN)+a1​z+⋯an​zn−1

such that when HHH is applied to this element, the constant term remains as s2mod  Ns^2 \mod Ns2modN which will be the output of the hash function. To do this, we will find an element in EEE with s2mod  Ns^2 \mod Ns2modN as its constant term, and then subtract zzz from it to account for the randomising value uuu which we can predict will be 111.

The element in KKK we are interested in is obtained by computing

(s2mod  N)e0−1zE−z=(s2mod  N)+a1z+⋯+anzn−1(s^2 \mod N) e_0^{-1} z_E - z = (s^2 \mod N) + a_1 z + \cdots + a_n z^{n-1}(s2modN)e0−1​zE​−z=(s2modN)+a1​z+⋯+an​zn−1

To send this to the server, we encode it as an integer:

an+an−1r+⋯+a1rn−2+(s2mod  N)rn−1a_n + a_{n-1} r + \cdots + a_1 r^{n-2} + (s^2 \mod N) r^{n-1}an​+an−1​r+⋯+a1​rn−2+(s2modN)rn−1

The server will compute for us a square root yyy of s2mod  Ns^2 \mod Ns2modN and if we have y≠±sy \neq \pm sy=±s, we can easily recover the private key using the technique described two sections ago.

Once we have the private key, we can use the provided functions in the handout code to sign the challenge message and capture the flag.

Easier Solution

I was made aware of this by S3v3ru5's solve during the CTF, but choosing the message to be signed can actually be quite simple (though fundamentally relies on most of the above theory); the idea is to shift the goal posts a bit and instead of trying to find a fixed message, we find a message whose hash is something we can control. We do this by noting that since xrn=xx^{r^n} = xxrn=x for all x∈Kx \in Kx∈K, then for any of our chosen x∈Kx \in Kx∈K, if we send xrn−m−zux^{r^{n - m}} - zuxrn−m−zu, then after being hashed, the result is exactly xxx. I imagine most teams would have solved this way instead of finding the subfield which is quite a bit more complicated. I obviously lacked the hindsight to spot this solution when writing the challenge, but it's pretty neat :)

Alternative Approach via Linearity Properties

This solution idea is due to rkm0959 who taught me this during the CTF after he solved it. Instead of looking at the fields involved, we can simply note that the hash function has some nice linearity properties. In particular

H(M,u)=H(M,0)+uH(0,1)(modr)H(M, u) = H(M, 0) + u H(0, 1) \pmod rH(M,u)=H(M,0)+uH(0,1)(modr)

So to forge a signature for any given MMM, we simply let x=1x = 1x=1 and solve for uuu:

x2=H(M,u)  ⟹  x=H(M,u)since x=1  ⟹  x=H(M,0)+uH(0,1)  ⟹  u=H(0,1)−1(x−H(M,0))\begin{aligned} x^2 &= H(M, u) \\ \implies x &= H(M, u) \qquad \text{since $x = 1$} \\ \implies x &= H(M, 0) + u H(0, 1) \\ \implies u &= H(0, 1)^{-1}(x - H(M, 0)) \end{aligned}x2⟹x⟹x⟹u​=H(M,u)=H(M,u)since x=1=H(M,0)+uH(0,1)=H(0,1)−1(x−H(M,0))​

Then, (x,u)(x, u)(x,u) is a valid signature for MMM.

This attack doesn't need to use the signing oracle and shows that the signature scheme is completely broken when using this hash function. Pretty cool solution!

Alternative Approach via Galois Theory

Alternatively, one might recognise the resemblance of the function fff with the Frobenius map ϕ:K→K,x↦xr\phi : K \rightarrow K, x \mapsto x^rϕ:K→K,x↦xr which is an Fr\mathbb{F}_rFr​-automorphism that generates the Galois group GGG of K/FrK/\mathbb{F}_rK/Fr​. Note that GGG is cyclic and of order nnn as ϕn:K→K,x↦xrn\phi^n : K \rightarrow K, x \mapsto x^{r^n}ϕn:K→K,x↦xrn is the identity map. The Fundamental Theorem of Galois Theory tells us that there is a one-to-one correspondence between the subgroups of the Galois group of KKK, and the intermediate fields of KKK. Explicitly, for a given subgroup HHH of GGG, the corresponding intermediate field of KKK is given by the fixed field KHK^HKH, the set of all elements in KKK which are fixed by all of the maps in HHH. Another result, sometimes known as the Fixed Field Theorem, tells us that the order of HHH is equal to the degree of KKK as an extension of KHK^HKH. We use this, along with the fact that the subfields of KKK are given by Frd\mathbb{F}_{r^d}Frd​ where ddd divides nnn, to find the fixed fields.

In the challenge, we have n=15n = 15n=15, so the Galois group GGG is isomorphic to Z/15Z\mathbb{Z}/15\mathbb{Z}Z/15Z. The table below lists out the subgroups of GGG and their corresponding intermediate fields (id\mathrm{id}id denotes the identity map):

Subgroup of GGGIntermediate Field of KKK
H0={id}H_0 = \{ \mathrm{id} \}H0​={id}KH0=KK^{H_0} = KKH0​=K (all elements are fixed by id\mathrm{id}id)
H1={id,ϕ5,ϕ10}H_1 = \{ \mathrm{id}, \phi^5, \phi^{10} \}H1​={id,ϕ5,ϕ10}KH1=Fr5K^{H_1} = \mathbb{F}_{r^5}KH1​=Fr5​
H2={id,ϕ3,ϕ6,ϕ9,ϕ12}H_2 = \{ \mathrm{id}, \phi^3, \phi^6, \phi^9, \phi^{12} \}H2​={id,ϕ3,ϕ6,ϕ9,ϕ12}KH2=Fr3K^{H_2} = \mathbb{F}_{r^3}KH2​=Fr3​
GGGKG=FrK^G = \mathbb{F}_rKG=Fr​ (only Fr\mathbb{F}_rFr​ is fixed by all automorphisms)

From this, we can see that Fr3\mathbb{F}_{r^3}Fr3​ is fixed by ϕ3\phi^3ϕ3.

1337crypt v2

The challenge claims to be a more complex version of 1337crypt from last year's DUCTF. Reading the solution for 1337crypt may help a bit with some initial ideas as both challenges play with the idea of partial knowledge. In both challenges, we are given hints to recover the prime factors, but the hints themselves seem to omit some bits of information. Specifically, the hints are the integer parts of some values that should actually contain a fractional part as well. As we will see (and as you may suspect :)), lattice techniques will help us to recover this missing information and therefore the primes.

Flag Encryption

We start by looking at how the flag is encrypted so that we have a clear idea of what we need to recover it. The flag is encrypted in a way very similar to RSA. The only difference is that instead of using integers, we use Gaussian integers. If you aren't familiar with Gaussian integers, I highly recommend reading this excellent blog post by CryptoHack for some extra background.

We work in the ring (Z/nZ)[i](\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z})[i](Z/nZ)[i] (we will just write this as Zn[i]\mathbb{Z}_n[i]Zn​[i]) where n=pqn = pqn=pq is the RSA modulus. The flag is encoded as an element mmm, of Zn[i]\mathbb{Z}_n[i]Zn​[i] by choosing a random integer r<nr < nr<n and computing m=r+flag⋅im = r + \mathrm{flag} \cdot im=r+flag⋅i.

The ciphertext is obtained by raising mmm to the eeeth power. In the challenge, eee is 0x1337.

To decrypt the ciphertext, we must find the multiplicative inverse of eee modulo the order of Zn[i]\mathbb{Z}_n[i]Zn​[i]. (Note: in this context, when we say "the order of Zn[i]\mathbb{Z}_n[i]Zn​[i]" we mean the cardinality of the multiplicative group of Zn[i]\mathbb{Z}_n[i]Zn​[i]) The order of Zn[i]\mathbb{Z}_n[i]Zn​[i] is φ(n)=(p−1)(q−1)\varphi(n) = (p-1)(q-1)φ(n)=(p−1)(q−1), so to compute it, we'll need to recover the primes.

Hints

The challenge generates 1337-bit primes ppp and qqq and gives us two hints, and the ciphertext. Using these hints, we need to recover ppp and qqq.

Hint 1

The first hint, which we will call DDD, is D=p2+q2D = p^2 + q^2D=p2+q2. This seems like a pretty big hint, and indeed if we were also given n=pqn = pqn=pq we could easily recover the primes by finding the roots of a simple univariate polynomial. As far as I am aware, DDD can't be used to directly recover ppp and qqq either; there are techniques such as factoring p2+q2=(p+qi)(p−qi)p^2 + q^2 = (p + qi)(p - qi)p2+q2=(p+qi)(p−qi) over the Gaussian integers, but this requires factoring DDD over the integers which may take a long time. That said, if you were able to find a solution using this hint alone I'd be interested in seeing it :)

Hint 2

There is a lot more going on in the second hint. But firstly, some background. Number field is just a fancy name for an (finite) extension of the rational numbers Q\mathbb{Q}Q. The simplest number field is Q\mathbb{Q}Q itself, and the rational complex numbers, Q(i)\mathbb{Q}(i)Q(i) is also a number field.

We can see that a number field is constructed from ppp and qqq. In Sage, the first argument to NumberField is the defining polynomial. The roots of this polynomial specify the elements to be adjoined to Q\mathbb{Q}Q to get the number field. We see that the defining polynomial for KKK is (x−p)2+q2(x-p)^2 + q^2(x−p)2+q2, which has roots p±qip \pm qip±qi. Therefore, we define

K=Q(p+qi)K = \mathbb{Q}(p + qi)K=Q(p+qi)

(side note: we only need to adjoin one root since the other, it's conjugate, can be obtained from the root with usual field operations). In the handout code, z=p+qiz = p + qiz=p+qi denotes this adjoined element.

Now, for the values we are given. We get two instances of values with the same form. For the jjjth hint (j=1,2j = 1, 2j=1,2), two 1337-bit numbers aja_jaj​ and bjb_jbj​ are generated, as well as two lll-bit numbers cjc_jcj​ and djd_jdj​. Then, xjx_jxj​ is computed as

xj=(aj+2−lcj)+(bj+2−ldj)zx_j = (a_j + 2^{-l} c_j) + (b_j + 2^{-l} d_j) zxj​=(aj​+2−lcj​)+(bj​+2−ldj​)z

Lastly,

∣xj∣2=xjxj‾|x_j|^2 = x_j \overline{x_j}∣xj​∣2=xj​xj​​

is computed and we are given the three values (⌊∣xj∣2⌋,aj,bj)(\lfloor |x_j|^2 \rfloor, a_j, b_j)(⌊∣xj​∣2⌋,aj​,bj​). Note that xj‾\overline{x_j}xj​​ denotes the complex conjugate of xjx_jxj​, so the value xjxj‾x_j \overline{x_j}xj​xj​​ gives us the squared complex modulus of xjx_jxj​. For ease of reading, we will write yyy instead of ⌊∣xj∣2⌋\lfloor |x_j|^2 \rfloor⌊∣xj​∣2⌋.

Importantly, we note that xjx_jxj​ is an element of KKK and its components are rational numbers with fractional parts. Similarly, ∣xj∣2|x_j|^2∣xj​∣2 is a rational number with a fractional part. However, we are only given the integer parts of these values, so it seems like we might be missing some information.

Solution

Let's analyse the second hint in further detail and see if we can use it to recover the primes directly, or find a relation involving the primes that will help us to do so.

Analysing Hint 2

There will be some tedious algebra, so to make things a bit more readable we will drop the subscripts. Note that we use hint 1 here since p2+q2p^2 + q^2p2+q2 appears. We have

x=(a+2−lc)+(b+2−ld)z=(a+2−lc)+(b+2−ld)(p+qi)=((a+2−lc)+(b+2−ld)p)+(b+2−ld)qi  ⟹  ∣x∣2=((a+2−lc)+(b+2−ld)p)2+((b+2−ld)q)2=(a+2−lc)2+2(a+2−lc)(b+2−ld)p+(b+2−ld)2p2+(b+2−ld)2q2=(a+2−lc)2+2(a+2−lc)(b+2−ld)p+(b+2−ld)2D=a2+2⋅2−lac+2−2lc2+2abp+2⋅2−ladp+2⋅2−lbcp+2⋅2−2lcdp+(b2+2⋅2−lbd+2−2ld2)D=a2+2⋅2−lac+2−2lc2+2abp+2⋅2−ladp+2⋅2−lbcp+2⋅2−2lcdp+b2D+2⋅2−lbdD+2−2ld2D\begin{aligned} x &= (a + 2^{-l} c) + (b + 2^{-l} d) z \\ &= (a + 2^{-l} c) + (b + 2^{-l} d) (p + qi) \\ &= ((a + 2^{-l} c) + (b + 2^{-l} d) p) + (b + 2^{-l} d) qi \\ \implies |x|^2 &= ((a + 2^{-l} c) + (b + 2^{-l} d) p)^2 + ((b + 2^{-l} d)q)^2 \\ &= (a + 2^{-l} c)^2 + 2(a + 2^{-l} c)(b + 2^{-l} d) p \\ &\quad + (b + 2^{-l} d)^2 p^2 + (b + 2^{-l} d)^2 q^2 \\ &= (a + 2^{-l} c)^2 + 2(a + 2^{-l} c)(b + 2^{-l} d) p + (b + 2^{-l}d)^2 D \\ &= a^2 + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} ac + 2^{-2l} c^2 + 2 a b p + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} adp + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} bcp + 2 \cdot 2^{-2l} c d p \\ &\quad + (b^2 + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} bd + 2^{-2l} d^2) D \\ &= a^2 + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} ac + 2^{-2l} c^2 + 2 a b p + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} adp + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} bcp + 2 \cdot 2^{-2l} c d p \\ &\quad + b^2 D + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} bd D + 2^{-2l} d^2 D \end{aligned}x⟹∣x∣2​=(a+2−lc)+(b+2−ld)z=(a+2−lc)+(b+2−ld)(p+qi)=((a+2−lc)+(b+2−ld)p)+(b+2−ld)qi=((a+2−lc)+(b+2−ld)p)2+((b+2−ld)q)2=(a+2−lc)2+2(a+2−lc)(b+2−ld)p+(b+2−ld)2p2+(b+2−ld)2q2=(a+2−lc)2+2(a+2−lc)(b+2−ld)p+(b+2−ld)2D=a2+2⋅2−lac+2−2lc2+2abp+2⋅2−ladp+2⋅2−lbcp+2⋅2−2lcdp+(b2+2⋅2−lbd+2−2ld2)D=a2+2⋅2−lac+2−2lc2+2abp+2⋅2−ladp+2⋅2−lbcp+2⋅2−2lcdp+b2D+2⋅2−lbdD+2−2ld2D​

Now, this looks like a mess and it kinda is, but fortunately we can clean it up a bit. Recall that aaa and bbb are 1337-bit numbers, while ccc and ddd are 338-bit numbers (l=338l = 338l=338). The following table gives the approximate size of each term (when considered as an integer), which we will use to reason with soon. Note that D=p2+q2D = p^2 + q^2D=p2+q2 is on the order of 2×13372 \times 13372×1337 bits.

TermSize (in bits)
a2a^2a22×13372 \times 13372×1337
2⋅2−lac2 \cdot 2^{-l} ac2⋅2−lac133713371337
2−2lc22^{-2l}c^22−2lc2000
2abp2abp2abp3×13373 \times 13373×1337
2⋅2−ladp2 \cdot 2^{-l} adp2⋅2−ladp2×13372 \times 13372×1337
2⋅2−lbcp2 \cdot 2^{-l} bcp2⋅2−lbcp2×13372 \times 13372×1337
2⋅2−2lcdp2 \cdot 2^{-2l} cdp2⋅2−2lcdp133713371337
b2Db^2 Db2D4×13374 \times 13374×1337
2⋅2−lbdD2 \cdot 2^{-l} bd D2⋅2−lbdD3×13373 \times 13373×1337
2−2ld2D2^{-2l} d^2 D2−2ld2D2×13372 \times 13372×1337

Now, what we will do is divide (integer division) the entire expression by 2ab2ab2ab. Because 2ab2ab2ab is around 2×13372 \times 13372×1337 bits in size, we can more or less throw away any term whose size is 2×13372 \times 13372×1337 or less. This leaves us with

∣x∣22ab=y2ab≈p+(b2+2⋅2−lbd)D2ab≈p+b2D2ab+2−ldDa\begin{aligned} \frac{|x|^2}{2ab} = \frac{y}{2ab} &\approx p + \frac{(b^2 + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} bd) D}{2ab} \\ &\approx p + \frac{b^2D}{2ab} + \frac{2^{-l}dD}{a} \end{aligned}2ab∣x∣2​=2aby​​≈p+2ab(b2+2⋅2−lbd)D​≈p+2abb2D​+a2−ldD​​

This approximation itself is very accurate, and only differs by a few bits due to the 2×13372 \times 13372×1337 terms. However, we don't know ddd, so this equation isn't as useful for us. Instead, we write

y2ab≈p+b2D2ab+⌊2−lDa⌋d=p+b2D2ab+⌊2−lDa⌋d+k\begin{aligned} \frac{y}{2ab} &\approx p + \frac{b^2 D}{2ab} + \left \lfloor \frac{2^{-l} D}{a} \right \rfloor d \\ &= p + \frac{b^2 D}{2ab} + \left \lfloor \frac{2^{-l} D}{a} \right \rfloor d + k \end{aligned}2aby​​≈p+2abb2D​+⌊a2−lD​⌋d=p+2abb2D​+⌊a2−lD​⌋d+k​

where ∣k∣<2l|k| < 2^l∣k∣<2l. Note that the approximation is off by a term of size approximately lll bits because of integer division rounding. We will omit the ⌊⌋\lfloor \rfloor⌊⌋, but it should be understood that we are performing integer division.

Using Hint 2

Now let's bring back the subscripts, noting that we have two instances:

{y12a1b1=p+b12D2a1b1+2−lDa1d1+k1y22a2b2=p+b22D2a2b2+2−lDa2d2+k2\begin{aligned} \begin{cases} \frac{y_1}{2a_1 b_1} &= p + \frac{b_1^2 D}{2 a_1 b_1} + \frac{2^{-l} D}{a_1} d_1 + k_1 \\ \frac{y_2}{2a_2 b_2} &= p + \frac{b_2^2 D}{2 a_2 b_2} + \frac{2^{-l} D}{a_2} d_2 + k_2 \\ \end{cases} \end{aligned}{2a1​b1​y1​​2a2​b2​y2​​​=p+2a1​b1​b12​D​+a1​2−lD​d1​+k1​=p+2a2​b2​b22​D​+a2​2−lD​d2​+k2​​​

Finally, let's combine these two equations to eliminate ppp.

y1−b12D2a1b1−2−lDa1d1−k1=y2−b22D2a2b2−2−lDa2d2−k2\frac{y_1 - b_1^2 D}{2 a_1 b_1} - \frac{2^{-l} D}{a_1} d_1 - k_1 = \frac{y_2 - b_2^2 D}{2 a_2 b_2}- \frac{2^{-l} D}{a_2} d_2 - k_22a1​b1​y1​−b12​D​−a1​2−lD​d1​−k1​=2a2​b2​y2​−b22​D​−a2​2−lD​d2​−k2​

Just so it's easier to read, let tj=yj−bj2D2ajbjt_j = \frac{y_j - b_j^2 D}{2 a_j b_j}tj​=2aj​bj​yj​−bj2​D​ and sj=2−lDajs_j = \frac{2^{-l} D}{a_j}sj​=aj​2−lD​. Then, rewriting the above equation, we have:

t1−s1d1−k1=t2−s2d2−k2t_1 - s_1 d_1 - k_1 = t_2 - s_2 d_2 - k_2t1​−s1​d1​−k1​=t2​−s2​d2​−k2​

or to put it in a more exciting way:

f(d1,d2,k)=t1−s1d1−t2+s2d2−k=0f(d_1, d_2, k) = t_1 - s_1 d_1 - t_2 + s_2 d_2 - k = 0f(d1​,d2​,k)=t1​−s1​d1​−t2​+s2​d2​−k=0

Now, fff has "small" integer roots d1,d2d_1, d_2d1​,d2​ and kkk. An algorithm for finding small roots of multivariate polyomials over the integers is described in this paper. Following a similar idea, defund's coppersmith implementation can also be used by working over an arbitrary ring Z/NZ\mathbb{Z}/N\mathbb{Z}Z/NZ for some large NNN.

Lattice Approach

However, we can also recover d1d_1d1​ and d2d_2d2​ with a very simple lattice. Consider the lattice generated by the rows of the following matrix:

[s110s201t1−t200]\begin{bmatrix} s_1 & 1 & 0 \\ s_2 & 0 & 1 \\ t_1 - t_2 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​s1​s2​t1​−t2​​100​010​⎦⎤​

The short vector (k,−d1,d2)(k, -d_1, d_2)(k,−d1​,d2​) is an element of this matrix, given by the linear combination of −d1-d_1−d1​ times the first row, d2d_2d2​ times the second row, and 111 times the third row. LLL finds this vector.

Recovering the Primes

Now that we have ddd, it is straightforward to recover ppp. We use the approximation we found earlier:

y2ab≈p+(b2+2⋅2−lbd)D2ab  ⟹  p≈y−(b2+2⋅2−lbd)D2ab\begin{aligned} \frac{y}{2ab} &\approx p + \frac{(b^2 + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} bd) D}{2ab} \\ \implies p &\approx \frac{y - (b^2 + 2 \cdot 2^{-l} bd) D}{2ab} \end{aligned}2aby​⟹p​≈p+2ab(b2+2⋅2−lbd)D​≈2aby−(b2+2⋅2−lbd)D​​

This approximation is accurate to all but a few bits, which we can easily exhaust over, checking if D−p2D - p^2D−p2 is a square to know which candidate for ppp is correct. We then compute qqq as the square root of D−p2D - p^2D−p2.

Getting the Flag

We've already discussed how to decrypt the ciphertext given that we have the prime factors. Compute d≡e−1(mod(p−1)(q−1))d \equiv e^{-1} \pmod{(p-1)(q-1)}d≡e−1(mod(p−1)(q−1)) as in regular RSA and raise ccc to the dddth power. The flag is in the imaginary component of the result.

Substitution Cipher III

This challenge is a sequel to "Substitution Cipher II", though in terms of difficulty, it is a large step up. The basis of the challenge is Patarin's famous attack (though other attacks may work) on the Matsumoto-Imai cryptosystem which was hinted towards by the bold MI in the challenge's description (one could easily find useful resources online by searching "MI cryptosystem"). The large public key size is also a trait of multivariate public key cryptosystems which some people may have recognised.

Like with the other two substitution cipher challenges, we are given the code which has been used to encrypt the flag, as well as the ciphertext. In this challenge, we are also given a public key.

Matsumoto-Imai Cryptosystem

In this section we give a rough description of the Matsumoto-Imai-like cryptosystem as presented in the challenge. There are some differences from the original cryptosystem, so to hopefully make it easier to follow, we also draw comparisons between the mathematical notation and the handout code.

The general idea is that a composition of certain transformations is difficult to invert without knowledge of the individual transformations that make it up; so a private key is made up of some invertible transformations, and the corresponding public key is their composition. Additionally, solving a set of multivariate (even quadratic) polynomial equations over a finite field in general is proven to be NP-complete, so one shouldn't be able to easily recover the plaintext from a given ciphertext and the public key alone.

Parameters

To set the scene, we choose parameters qqq and nnn (in the challenge q=2q = 2q=2 and n=80n = 80n=80) and define some algebraic objects to work with:

K=Fq[x1,…,xn]E=K[t]/(i(t))L=E[x]A=Aff(n,K)\begin{aligned} K &= \mathbb{F}_q[x_1, \ldots, x_n] \\ E &= K[t]/(i(t)) \\ L &= E[x] \\ A &= \mathrm{Aff}(n, K) \end{aligned}KELA​=Fq​[x1​,…,xn​]=K[t]/(i(t))=E[x]=Aff(n,K)​

where i(t)i(t)i(t) is an arbitrary degree nnn irreducible polynomial.

In Sage, we need to write a bit more boilerplate to achieve this:

    q = 2
    F = GF(q)
    K = BooleanPolynomialRing(n, 'x')
    R.<t> = PolynomialRing(K)
    i = GF(q)[t].irreducible_element(n)
    I = Ideal(R(i))
    I.reduce = lambda f: f % i # dirty sage hack
    E.<tbar> = PolynomialRing(K, t).quo(I)
    L.<x> = PolynomialRing(E)
    A = AffineGroup(n, K)
  • BooleanPolynomialRing is a more efficient implementation of boolean polynomials; in most cases it can be used as a clean replacement for GF(2)[x1, ..., xn].
  • As for the I.reduce = ... line, this should probably not need to be done but I was having difficulties getting Sage to properly reduce elements of EEE modulo i(t)i(t)i(t) and this seemed like the only way to fix it.
  • The purpose of LLL is to define polynomials whose variables are in EEE (which we'll do next).
  • AAA is defined so that we can easily work with affine transformations.

Private Key

Next, we'll generate the private key. We choose random S,T∈AS, T \in AS,T∈A and P=rxq+1∈LP = r x^{q + 1} \in LP=rxq+1∈L where r∈Er \in Er∈E is randomly chosen. (Note that the construction of PPP here is not in its most general form, and that this particular choice of PPP is potentially weaker than other choices).

In Sage, we write:

    S = A(GL(n, F).random_element(), random_vector(F, n), check=False)
    r = sum(randint(0, 1) * tbar^i for i in range(n))
    P = r * x^(q + 1)
    T = A(GL(n, F).random_element(), random_vector(F, n), check=False)

A.random_element() wasn't working for some reason, so we simply generate a random invertible matrix and a random vector with elements in Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​ which is enough to represent an affine transformation.

Public Key

To derive the public key RRR from the private key, we simply take the composition R=T∘P∘SR = T \circ P \circ SR=T∘P∘S.

Actually, that's not entirely correct but it captures the general idea. To be more explicit, SSS and TTT are affine transformations that map elements of KnK^nKn to elements of KnK^nKn, whereas PPP is a function that takes an element in EEE and outputs an element in EEE. The way we glue together these components of different "types" is by introducing an extra function that converts between the two types; there is a natural bijection between KnK^nKn and EEE, so we define:

φ:Kn→E(v0,v1,…,vn−1)↦v0+v1t+⋯+vn−1tn−1\begin{aligned} \varphi : K^n &\rightarrow E \\ (v_0, v_1, \ldots, v_{n-1}) &\mapsto v_0 + v_1 t + \cdots + v_{n-1} t^{n-1} \end{aligned}φ:Kn(v0​,v1​,…,vn−1​)​→E↦v0​+v1​t+⋯+vn−1​tn−1​

So more accurately, we take the public key to be R=T∘φ−1∘P∘φ∘SR = T \circ \varphi^{-1} \circ P \circ \varphi \circ SR=T∘φ−1∘P∘φ∘S.

RRR itself can be represented by nnn multivariate polynomials r1,r2,…,rnr_1, r_2, \ldots, r_nr1​,r2​,…,rn​; these are what will be used for encryption.

In Sage, we can write this concisely as:

    B = S(K.gens()) * vector([tbar^i for i in range(n)])
    Q = P(B)
    R = T(Q.lift().coefficients())

Since SSS and TTT are elements of AAA, we can perform the transformation they represent with S(x) and T(x) respectively, where x is an element of KnK^nKn. Multiplication by the vector (1,t,…,tn−1)(1, t, \ldots, t^{n-1})(1,t,…,tn−1) is equivalent to the conversion map φ\varphiφ, and taking the coefficients of an element in EEE is equivalent to φ−1\varphi^{-1}φ−1. The reason for the .lift() is to consider Q as an element of K[t]K[t]K[t] (as opposed to an element of EEE) since .coefficients() seems to be not implemented for this quotient ring.

Encryption

Encryption is easy but there is a slight caveat that might be confusing. The public polynomials ri:Kn→Kr_i : K^n \rightarrow Kri​:Kn→K map elements of KnK^nKn to an element of KKK. We defined KKK to be a boolean polynomial ring, but it should be noted that Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​ is a subset of KKK, and that Fqn\mathbb{F}_q^nFqn​ is a subset of KnK^nKn. When we encrypt messages, we are really only concerned with the subset Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​ and not with other elements of KKK. (This is just for the reason that working with bits is easier; there shouldn't be any issues with encoding messages using other elements in KKK)

To encrypt a message, we first encode the message as an element mmm of Fqn\mathbb{F}_q^nFqn​ and compute (r1(m),r2(m),…,rn(m))(r_1(m), r_2(m), \ldots, r_n(m))(r1​(m),r2​(m),…,rn​(m)). where rir_iri​ are the public polynomials. Since each of the rir_iri​ sends elements of Fqn\mathbb{F}_q^nFqn​ to an element in Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​, the resulting ciphertext is an element of Fqn⊂Kn\mathbb{F}_q^n \subset K^nFqn​⊂Kn.

Solution

We are given nothing but the public key and the ciphertexts. We could attempt to recover the private key, but it isn't necessary. We will follow Patarin's attack from Crypto'95 which allows us to recover the plaintext for any given ciphertext.

The attack relies on the fact that maps f:E→Ef : E \rightarrow Ef:E→E of the form x↦xqkx \mapsto x^{q^k}x↦xqk are linear for any integer kkk. By this, we mean that if z=z0+z1t+⋯+zn−1tn−1∈Ez = z_0 + z_1 t + \cdots + z_{n-1} t^{n-1} \in Ez=z0​+z1​t+⋯+zn−1​tn−1∈E, then f(z)=z0′+z1′t+⋯+zn−1′tn−1f(z) = z_0' + z_1' t + \cdots + z_{n-1}' t^{n-1}f(z)=z0′​+z1′​t+⋯+zn−1′​tn−1 is such that zi′=fi(z0,…,zn−1)z_i' = f_i(z_0, \ldots, z_{n-1})zi′​=fi​(z0​,…,zn−1​) with deg⁡fi=1\deg f_i = 1degfi​=1. In words; this says that the coefficients of f(z)f(z)f(z) can be written as a linear combination of the coefficients of zzz.

I couldn't find a proof for this, (maybe because it's supposed to be obvious, but it certainly wasn't obvious to me), so here is my (possibly wrong) attempt at a justification (which I think might actually only work for q=2q = 2q=2):

Define f:E→Ef : E \rightarrow Ef:E→E as f(x)=xqkf(x) = x^{q^k}f(x)=xqk for any integer kkk. Let z=z0+z1t+⋯+zn−1tn−1∈Ez = z_0 + z_1 t + \cdots + z_{n-1} t^{n-1} \in Ez=z0​+z1​t+⋯+zn−1​tn−1∈E. Then

f(z)=(z0+z1t+⋯+zn−1tn−1)qk=z0qk+(z1t)qk+⋯+(zn−1tn−1)qksince char(E)=q=z0+z1tqk+⋯+zn−1t(n−1)qksince x=xq for all x∈K\begin{aligned} f(z) &= (z_0 + z_1 t + \cdots + z_{n-1} t^{n-1})^{q^k} \\ &= z_0^{q^k} + (z_1 t)^{q^k} + \cdots + (z_{n-1} t^{n-1})^{q^k} \quad \text{since } \mathrm{char}(E) = q \\ &= z_0 + z_1 t^{q^k} + \cdots + z_{n-1} t^{(n-1)q^k} \quad \text{since } x = x^q \text{ for all } x \in K \end{aligned}f(z)​=(z0​+z1​t+⋯+zn−1​tn−1)qk=z0qk​+(z1​t)qk+⋯+(zn−1​tn−1)qksince char(E)=q=z0​+z1​tqk+⋯+zn−1​t(n−1)qksince x=xq for all x∈K​

It should now follow that, after being reduced modulo the irreducible polynomial i(t)i(t)i(t), the coefficients of f(z)f(z)f(z) are linear combinations of the ziz_izi​.

Combined with some other clever insights, this eventually leads to a linear expression relating all plaintext and ciphertext pairs as we will soon see.

Finding the Relation

This is the core of the attack. To begin, recall that a plaintext message x∈Knx \in K^nx∈Kn is encrypted by computing its ciphertext y=(T∘φ−1∘P∘φ∘S)(x)∈Kny = (T \circ \varphi^{-1} \circ P \circ \varphi \circ S)(x) \in K^ny=(T∘φ−1∘P∘φ∘S)(x)∈Kn.

Let a=φ(S(x))a = \varphi(S(x))a=φ(S(x)) and b=φ(T−1(y))b = \varphi(T^{-1}(y))b=φ(T−1(y)). Note that a,b∈Ea, b \in Ea,b∈E and furthermore that b=P(a)b = P(a)b=P(a). So we have

b=raq+1b = ra^{q + 1}b=raq+1

Now, applying g:E→E,x↦xq−1g : E \rightarrow E, x \mapsto x^{q-1}g:E→E,x↦xq−1 to both sides of the equation, we get

g(b)=g(raq+1)bq−1=rq−1aq2−1\begin{aligned} g(b) &= g(ra^{q+1}) \\ b^{q-1} &= r^{q-1} a^{q^2 - 1} \end{aligned}g(b)bq−1​=g(raq+1)=rq−1aq2−1​

Multiplying both sides by ababab, we get

abq=rq−1aq2b(1)ab^q = r^{q-1} a^{q^2} b \tag{1}abq=rq−1aq2b(1)

By the definition of aaa and bbb, we have

a=c1x+c2b=c3y+c4a = c_1x + c_2 \qquad b = c_3 y + c_4a=c1​x+c2​b=c3​y+c4​

where the cic_ici​ are elements of EEE which we do not particularly care about. This follows because aaa and bbb are simply affine transformations of xxx and yyy respectively.

Combining this with the fact that the maps b↦bqb \mapsto b^qb↦bq and a↦aq2a \mapsto a^{q^2}a↦aq2 are linear maps, equation (1)(1)(1) effectively gives us an equation relating xxx and yyy where xxx, yyy and xyxyxy appear to a power of no greater than 111.

So, if we let x=(x0,x1,…,xn−1)x = (x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_{n-1})x=(x0​,x1​,…,xn−1​) and y=(y0,y1,…,yn−1)y = (y_0, y_1, \ldots, y_{n-1})y=(y0​,y1​,…,yn−1​), then the information given by equation (1)(1)(1) can be rewritten as:

∑i=0n−1∑j=0n−1γi,jxiyj+∑i=0n−1αixi+∑j=0n−1βjyj+δ=0(2)\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \gamma_{i, j} x_i y_j + \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \alpha_i x_i + \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \beta_j y_j + \delta = 0 \tag{2}i=0∑n−1​j=0∑n−1​γi,j​xi​yj​+i=0∑n−1​αi​xi​+j=0∑n−1​βj​yj​+δ=0(2)

And the amazing thing about this relation is that it holds for all plaintext/ciphertext pairs (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) since we made no assumptions about them to begin with! That means it holds for the flag and the ciphertext we've been given too :)

Recovering the Constants

Equation (2)(2)(2) gives us a relation that holds for all plaintext/ciphertext pairs, but we don't know the γi,j,αi,βj\gamma_{i, j}, \alpha_i, \beta_jγi,j​,αi​,βj​ and δ\deltaδ. Fortunately, since encryption uses the public key (which we have), we can generate our own plaintexts and encrypt them to get valid plaintext/ciphertext pairs.

With a set of plaintext/ciphertext pairs, we can view equation (2)(2)(2) as a system of linear equations in the unknowns γi,j,αi,βj\gamma_{i, j}, \alpha_i, \beta_jγi,j​,αi​,βj​ and δ\deltaδ and use linear algebra techniques to solve for them. There are n2+n+n+1=(n+1)2n^2 + n + n + 1 = (n+1)^2n2+n+n+1=(n+1)2 unknowns, so we'll need (n+1)2(n+1)^2(n+1)2 plaintext/ciphertext pairs to successfully recover the constants.

Generating the plaintext/ciphertext pairs may take a while (though, not that long if you're patient), so an easy optimisation we can do is choose sparse plaintext vectors; that is, plaintexts which have a lot of zero bits. Doing this speeds up polynomial evaluation which is the most expensive operation for encryption.

Recovering the Flag

The hard work is mostly done. If we have the relation and the constants, then to recover a plaintext given a ciphertext all we need to do is plug in the yjy_jyj​ values, and solve for the xix_ixi​ values. Again, this is done using linear algebra techniques, but in this case instead of solving a system of linear equations in the unknowns γi,j,αi,βj\gamma_{i, j}, \alpha_i, \beta_jγi,j​,αi​,βj​ and δ\deltaδ, we solve the system for the unknowns x0,x1,…,xn−1x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_{n-1}x0​,x1​,…,xn−1​.
